messages.subject: Re: [samuraihistory] tokugawa Iyasu, last great battle.
messages.msgSnippet: ... Osaka, in 1615, the winter/summer campaign to reduce the castle. But you re probably thinking of the big battle of Sekigahara in October of 1600. Tony
messages.messageBody:
lee thompson wrote:

> could anyone tell me the name of the battle feild in
> which Iyasu fought his last battle?
>

Osaka, in 1615, the winter/summer campaign to reduce the castle.

But you're probably thinking of the big battle of Sekigahara in October of
1600.


Tony

messages.subject: Slan go foil, Sayonara, Auf weiderzeihn, etc. etc.
messages.msgSnippet: In no way do I mean to be rude by BCC-ing this mail to everyone, but it would be rather intensive to mail each list personally, seeing as I m on over 30 of
messages.messageBody:
In no way do I mean to be rude by BCC-ing this mail to everyone, but it would be rather intensive to mail each list personally,
seeing as I'm on over 30 of them!

So please do not be offended by this mail.
I formerly apologise for it's off-topic-ness, because this is a mail for a few reasons, some irrelevant. Please read on.

I want to thank everyone that has ever replied to my queries. Your guidance on my many questions has helped me understand the little
and the large things in life over the year that I've been on these lists.
To you, I say thank you very much.

The reason I need to leave you is because I need to brave the big world alone now, as I'm moving to pastures anew. I have left home,
and will be unable to continue my life of relative luxury as I have it now at home with my parents.

Unfortunately, there are not the facilities in my new home to keep up with the huge volume of mail that I regularly get off of the
lists that I have subscribed to.
Thus, it would be best to leave for a while.

I will miss reading the mails that have been posted on all the lists that I'm on, as they have held huge volumes of information for
me, and will continue to do so in the future.

Thanks again to EVERYONE who's helped either me and even everyone else, because in helping them, you've already shown me how to
overcome their ailment should it ever befall me.

I will miss you all!!!!

Kumo.

Natsu-gusa ya
Tsuamono-domo ga
yume no ato

- Basho Matsuo.
(1644 - 1694)
